abstract.value: These papers document the career of Newell Dwight Hillis (1858 -1929), a noted clergyman, lecturer and author of his day. The bulk of the papers reflect Dr. Hillis's activities during his years at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn (1899-1924).

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Newell Dwight Hillis papers, 1985.004, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Newell Dwight Hillis died on February 5, 1929.

The scope and content of the writings and sermons, ephemera, clippings, scrapbooks, family papers, and photographs are included in the series descriptions.  The collection is arranged into the following eight series:

dsc.value:
Series 1: Correspondence64881892-1928Scope and Contents

The correspondence covers all aspects of Hillis's professional life. The bulk of the letters fall between 1913 and 1918 and relate to Plymouth Church business, especially plans for the Beecher Memorial and ongoing construction of the Plymouth Institute, and Hillis's personal and business affairs, lecture tours, and publications. A major portion of the correspondence is from parishoners and other followers of Hillis. These are generally letters of support and thanks, or requests for copies of sermons and publications. Hillis's replies to these letters are mostly absent from the series.

Series 2: Writings and sermons64891891-1925Scope and Contents

This series contains sermons, addresses, and articles by Hillis in a variety of formats, including newsprint, typescripts, and pamphlets. The majority of these are clippings of sermons from the Brooklyn Eagle.

Series 3: Business and financial records64901898-1928Scope and Contents

This series includes records such as personal business and financial papers, contracts with lecture agencies, and financial records relating to Plymouth Church business and the Henry Ward Beecher Memorial Association. Of special interest are financial records relating to the construction of the Memorial and the Plymouth Institute, and papers relating to the Alberini timber bonds, which were a major element in Hillis's financial difficulties. A budget sheet for the Mayflower Mission Soup Kitchen operated by Plymouth Church in 1914 is also included.

Series 4: Ephemera6491Scope and Contents

This series includes photographs, lecture schedules, and promotional brochures for Hillis's speaking engagements and publications. Also included are Plymouth Church bulletins, programs from tributes to Hillis, and assorted brochures relating to people and organizations with whom Hillis was involved. Folder 1 contains a biography of Hillis titled 25 Years at Plymouth Church, which appears to have been written by his secretary, Lucie L. Whitlock, upon his resignation from the Church.

The letter collection which is filed here contains assorted letters from Henry Ward Beecher, Booker T. Washington, and others. Most of these letters are not addressed to Hillis. A few have notes by Richard Hillis attached.

Series 5: General clippings64921898-1961OS-41Scope and Contents

This series contains newspaper and magazine clippings relating to Dr. Hillis, Plymouth Church, and persons involved with the Church. Topics of special interest include the Henry Ward Beecher Memorial and Brooklyn beautification plans.

Series 6: Scrapbooks64931895-1918Scope and Contents

Of the five scrapbooks in the collection, three were disassembled and filed in the order in which they appeared in the volumes. Items in Scrapbooks II and IV were given numbers, while items in Scrapbook V were in chronological order and were filed that way. Scrapbooks I and III remain intact.

Series 7: Family papers64941901-1964Scope and Contents

This series includes the papers and correspondence of Annie Louise Hillis, Richard Hillis, and Marjorie Hillis Roulston, as well as one letter from Irwin Bachellor to Reverend Hillis regarding the Lake Placid Country Club. The papers of Marjorie Hillis Roulston include a typescript copy of her biographical essay on her father, which was published in A Church History: The Story of Plymouth's First Hundred Years Under Beecher, Abbott, Hillis, Durkee and Fifield.

Series 8: Photographs6495Scope and Contents

This series consists of one folder of black-and-white photographs depicting Newell Dwight Hillis, members of the Hillis family, and various colleagues and associates of Hillis, mostly unidentified; and one half-manuscript box of images used in Hillis's lectures.
